div.p: VS. Bos 0, i : i 17. Favre-Nicolin II -P. Monceau CRTBT-CNRS, 38042 Grenoble <: H. Requardt ILL 38042 Grenoble R. Currat II -Report:

In this experiment we have used the Energy Dispersive Diffraction technique to study the energy dependence of the intensity of some selected Bragg and superlattice reflections of the quasi-one-dimensional conductor (TaSe&I. This compound undergoes a Peierls transition at Tc=263K with the appearence of new superlattice reflections. The experiment has been performed at the Lnl edge of Ta (E=9876 eV), and the energy band was 800 eV. The goal of the experiment was to determine if there is an optical component of the Ta atoms atomic displacement in the incommensurate state. It is easy to show that in this case the energy variation of the intensity for the Bragg and satellites has to be different. Figure 1 shows typical images obtained for this compound below the phase transition temperature. Figure 2 shows a cut of the image in figure I where we see an intense signal, the Bragg peak, surrounded by 4 of smaller intensity (the satellites). The reason why these appear so close to the fundamental is because the wavevector of the modulation is very small: q=(+O.O5, kO.05, +O.OSj). Quantitative data analysis, incommensurate structure refinement taking into account all the wavelengths in the spectra, of the whole image (20 Bra gg reflections and the corresponding satellites) is on the way.
